description:
First though, another glimpse into the future. We heard last week from Chris Milk who's working at the forefront of the new immersive technology of virtual reality. This week, though, the emphasis is on performance, human performance captured digitally and then visually manipulated, to bring us Gollum in Lord of the Rings, for example, or King Kong, or the alpha ape Caesar in the recent Dawn of the Planet of the Apes. All roles that originated with the award-winning actor Andy Serkis, recognised as the preeminent practitioner of performance capture as dramatic art. Together with producer Jonathan Cavendish, he's set up The Imaginarium Studios to develop what they call next generation's storytelling. Andy Serkis explained why.

The Imaginarium Studios came about as a result of wanting to create a way of using digital avatars in not only movies, but also in television and in video games. For me, it started way back in 2000 when I was working in New Zealand on Lord of the Rings. And having worked with Weta, the visual effects company down there, and discovering the joys of it, how liberating it was as an acting tool. When Jonathan and I got together, we decided that it would be a good idea to create, in the UK, a centre, a kind of epicentre, I suppose, for performance capture not only for playing characters in major budget movies, but also expanding into lots of other arenas.
